ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Kane, Daniel
Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Dan Kane
Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Dan Kane
Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Kyra Prats
Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  kyra prats
Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Prats, Kyra
Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Kyra Prats
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Ganz Taylor
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Taylor Ganz
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  I worked with Taylor Ganz.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Dan is an excellent teacher and discussion leader. He genuinely cared about students' comprehension and achievement. Only possible thing to improve on is public speaking skills (brevity and style), but overall very well done.
Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Knew his subject matter and was very involved and accessible.
Instructor: Daniel Aloysius Kane  Dan was an excellent teacher all the way through the course. Very knowledgeable in the lab and field. He was great to work with.
Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Kyra, was exceptional in her position. Her comments were often and constructive.

Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Kyra was extremely helpful, and went out of her way to ensure the forest group understood what was expected of us as far as our management plan and presentation. She was always proactive in setting expectations and giving advice, so we weren't held up waiting for her to get to things. In lab she was a great resource for the specific techniques that many of us were unfamiliar with, and at the Branford property she was a great help with tree ID. All that said, I also think Kyra did a good job of not just telling us the answers, but instead letting us figure things out for ourselves.

Instructor: Kyra Alexandra Prats  Kyra was super helpful! She went above and beyond to help us with field work, developing our management plan and editing our plan. She was always willing and happy to meet with us outside of class/lab hours. Best teacher assistant I've ever had!
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Offered help and was responsive to questions. When we were working on something that she was not familiar with, she was able to tell us who to talk to.
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Accessible but not always helpful. Probably not entirely her fault though - the structure of the class kept her very separate from our lecture material.

Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Taylor was rarely available to meet with our team and was not helpful when she did meet with us. I found myself going to the other TAs in the class for guidance she Taylor never gave complete or relevant answers to questions. We would sometimes ask if we were doing things correctly and she would respond with vague answers as if she wanted us to be independent but it just seemed like she didn't know the answers. She blamed team members for not doing extra hours in the lab and was completely unhelpful in the isotope lab. We were essentially left to our own devices and weren't given the skills or guidance to conduct our research properly.
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  She is okay.
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Good overall but was not a specialist in our ecosystem
Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Taylor knows quite a bit about water, but not much about salt marshes, so she was not particularly helpful as we put together our final projects.

Instructor: Taylor Renee Ganz  Taylor was generally helpful during the labs, particularly in gathering the data. However, she did not provide very much guidance and was difficult to meet with for questions.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Overall I really appreciated the flip lecture format for the first half of the class. That said, in the instances with especially complex content I think it would have been helpful to have a second in-class lecture that is basically a repeat in order to reinforce the material. The Q&A periods were helpful, but sometimes it's hard to know what your question actually is or how to articulate it. I would have enjoyed a last field trip towards the end of the course, since we didn't know that much in the beginning. It would have been exciting to see the contrast.

For Question 3 - I decline to answer this question because I only audited the course so my perception of the workload is likely not an accurate reflection of the actual workload. Similarly, for Questions 8-10, I did not attend the field portion of this course since I was auditing. This includes all questions regarding the Teaching Fellow, since they were mostly involved with the field lab portion of the course.
Both professors were amazing.

Question 15: This course was valuable in ways I was not expecting. I went into it thinking it would be a standard ecological science course. While the science was an important part of the course, it was much more heavily focused on the philosophical aspects of environmental management and on systems thinking. Rather than coming away with a bunch of new science concepts in my head, I came away with new ways of thinking about how humans interact with nature as a whole.
I will comment on following boxes.
13. Mark's instruction style is not particularly clear or polished, but he makes up for it by being very responsive and helpful outside of class.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The systems approach to ecology. The acknowledgment of what we do know and what we don't know.
Instructor enthusiasm and knowledge of material

I especially enjoyed the last third or so of this course, and the way it built on the first two thirds. I appreciated the large-scope of the lectures, and the incorporation of big questions about the role of science, economics/cost-benefit analysis, the peer review process, etc. I also found both projects very helpful in cementing my understanding of certain concepts and developing a deeper understanding of some specific issues/places.

I found the flipped class format to be especially useful in this course. I believe it allowed for productive conversation during class time. I also appreciated the professors reviewing any questions about the recorded lecture at the beginning of each class.
The thinking process this class lends to other systems.
The course itself was an interesting introduction to ecosystem science, and was great at zooming in and out between the current science and the value of it to management and policy.

I gained the most from Os's lectures on systems thinking and how we need to rethink our relationship with nature in the anthropocene. These lectures were very well thought out and provided numerous examples of the concepts we were discussing. On several occasions, we would end class and immediately sit down at the tables in Kroon to keep discussing the material presented in the lecture.
The thoughtful discussions in the latter half of the course tying together the science, anthropology, ethics, etc of conservation.
Being able to conduct some field work was immensely helpful. I would love it if there were more field-based classes at FES.

Getting out in the field was great. We learned new skills and how to take field samples, analyze them in the lab, and report them in reports. The lectures were also very good- especially in the second half when Oz lectured.
The big picture of how to understand ecosystem and the explanations from professor Os.
The overall message, contextual lectures, reading critiques

The twist that the course took, from being very rooted in the physical/mechanical functioning of ecosystems to exploring the implications of accounting for humans in the environment, was a bit unexpected and pleasantly surprising. Writing management plans was also a useful exercise.
I particularly enjoyed the lectures at the end of the course, where we discussed the role of humans in ecosystems.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Clarity in assignment goals and due dates.

Structure/content of classes where discussion is the primary goal of that class. Often we got bogged down in details or lecture, which took away from discussion. The size and arrangement of the classroom also inhibited quality of discussion.

The group size of the management plan group was my biggest complaint -- too big! This was problematic for a number of reasons (diffusion of responsibility, hard to schedule meeting times that work for everyone, some people get off without doing much, you don't get to be involved in everything personally).
From my experience of auditing the course, I do not see any major areas of improvement.
Balanced work between in class and out of class work, throughout the semester.

At the beginning of the course, the pace was to fast and the material presented seemed too advanced. This is an introductory course that doesn't have prerequisites. The first classes were really hard to follow without any background on the topics.

The beginning of the semester is very information heavy. It's important that we have all this information in order to get the most out of the second half of the semester, but I think it could have been presented in a clearer fashion. I think rather than have classes that go beyond what we watched in the online lectures, it would have been beneficial to very slowly review the same material. I think this portion of the course should be taught with the understanding that many students have almost no ecological science background. Slightly more organization on the front end could have improved this.

It would have been helpful for better explanation at the beginning of the semester as to how the curse would be structured. The course was very front loaded (rightfully so) with a lot of scientific material, but that situation was only brought up halfway through the semester. Warning or preparing us at the beginning of the course's overall structure would have been helpful.

It would be helpful if the TAs engaged in class work as well so they had a better understanding of what the course content includes. Hiring decisions should be more thoughtful since our TA was relatively useless. She didn't appear to know the material herself.
The workload was strenuous in the beginning with all of our other courses. The professors lightened the load after multiple student requests. Some readings I felt were poor choices for the class.
probably a little bit more credit hours and less workload every week.
It was sometimes heavy on the group work (two simultaneous group projects) and the groups were too large for the final project.
There is not a good flow from topic to topic or instructor to instructor. Overall the class felt disjointed and it was difficult to know where everything was going.
The homework assignments and group projects could use more guidance and explanation to clarify the end goals and expectations.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was limited connection, they could be intertwined a bit more but I don't feel that it such as through the overuse of fertilizers in conventional agriculture, away from my learning experience significantly.
Well done. Lab work comprised a large amount of total time required by the course.

I admit that this relationship felt slightly tenuous to start, but looking back I understand that we had to get started with the lab component right off in order to meet our end of semester deadline. I think it might have been helpful to have a lecture devoted to the goals of the management plan project, the different components of work, and the final product upfront. This would have given us a little more context for the specific labs as we made our way through the semester. Perhaps we could have been given a few example plans to read upfront to get a better sense of what we were shooting for? These could be from past students, or professional management plans developed by foresters, etc. I'd also add that the tour of the isotope lab went completely over my head. I basically had no idea what they were talking about or how it related to our lab. I also found it difficult to ask questions because I didn't understand a lot of the words they were using. It might be helpful to have Mark and/or Os present for the tour next year in order to target it more to our class.

Yes, as mentioned above, I found the flipped lectures to be extremely useful in relation to the discussion section during the class period. I found it particularly when slight variations on exercises presented in the online lecture were repeated in person in the classroom.
Yes.
Pretty well reflected, especially since Oz and Mark were so open to questions.
In the end the lab work made sense but at the beginning it was hard to understand for someone without background on carbon or nitrogen cycles.

Very disjointed, but that was okay. It was like having two separate classes in one and I appreciate everything that was crammed in. But n terms of improvement, just better communication and instruction about the lab days would be helpful.
I thought the connection between field work and class work was well done and the flow of the class modules made logical sense. More field trips would have been appreciated.
It is good
Highly effective, more context for the flow and rationale for the progression of topics up front could have been helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Review of ecological concepts.

As a first year student I felt that the last part of this course primed me to think about how to pursue the important questions Mark and Os introduced on my own throughout the rest of my time at FES. I strongly believe every student entering FES should take this course. It is more than a science course. It is an introduction to thinking about the world as an environmental professional, and I found it invaluable. I think this course will fit into the rest of my program as a course that increased my scientific literacy, and understanding of how science fits into management decisions made by professionals in a variety of fields.
I wanted to learn about how landscapes function, especially in coastal settings. The work in Jarvis Creek was perfect for this.

This course really tied together my ecology background with the realities of environmental management - the complex dynamics of problem solving. I really appreciated the mixture of focused topics and big picture discussions. I feel like this course was a great way to start off my program at FES because it revealed complexity in all aspects of environmental science and management as well taught me how to analyze from all angles.
This is a good class and I really like it.
Loved this course overall!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To review ecological concepts and learn from accomplished researchers.
I took this class as someone who does not have a science background in order to boost my scientific literacy. It accomplished that goal, and so much more that I didn't expect.
I took this course because I did not have any prior experience with ecosystem science and I hope to pursue a career that blends ecology and engineering.
It fits into my focus and desired field.
I wanted an introduction to fieldwork, and I liked that it would take place in the salt marsh.
I took this course because I had almost no background ecological science.
It's a foundations course.
I took this course to get a better understanding of ecology and earth systems. I also heard excellent reviews of both professors and enjoyed working with professor Bradford during mods.
I really want to learn how to evaluate the ecosystem systematically
To get a better understanding of the fundamentals of ecosystem functioning- this course delivered!

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Absolutely plus even more!

Yes, the course provided a strong foundational understanding of ecosystem science and landscape ecology. I feel like the knowledge and skills acquired from this course can be applied to a variety of management situations.
Yes
Sort of. I would love to do more field work, but I don't think that I gained that much strength in that area.

the course was a good and comprehensive class on ecological systems. After the class I am so much better at understanding these systems and how to manage them that the course completely met my expectations.

The knowledge I gained from this course was somewhat different than I expected. That being said, I think the knowledge I gained was very important and almost more important than what I thought I would be learning. This course changed the way I think about environmental management, rather than simply providing me with hard scientific skills.
Yes, I learned enough to have a foundation in ecological principles.
Yes, the skills we learned were very appropriate.
I think I learned a lot from this class and this is very good.
Yes

Yes. Again, writing the management plans was a great exercise. It was also interesting wrestling with how best to include humans in our conception of the environment. These conversations really expanded my thinking.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group project guidelines could have been clarified more. I felt that the class group project on ecosystem budgeting was a little scattered. We were given instructions for the 2nd and 3rd part of the assignment a day before the 1st part was due. If I had been aware of the requirements of the entire project in the beginning, I would have chosen a different system to work on for the semester that I would have gained more from.

Group work is a blessing and a curse. The size of the groups for final projects was frustrating (too large). I am unsure if that is the intent (learn how to work with large groups), or a function of the number of TAs available and the property where field work takes place. In any case, if the groups could be smaller each individual might learn more and the quality of work could improve.

Overall I found both group projects challenging, but that is largely a personality issue as I tend to prefer working independently. That said, I found the management plan group project especially unwieldy given the large group size. With a group that size there is automatically a diffusion of responsibility, and some people end up doing more work than others. In addition, no one seems to fully understand everything. In future years I think it would helpful to cap the group size at 7 or 8 maximum. I liked that we kept the same group for the budget project throughout the three phases. We definitely improved from project to project as far as working together, etc.
I felt many others did not put in the requisite amount of work.
Different levels of commitment and large group sizes. Besides that, very useful.

I think the main disadvantage of the group work was that it made it challenging for the people who had less experience in this subject area to ever feel caught up. With big groups, it was easy to feel like certain people had a very strong understanding and didn't need to slow down to explain everything to those who were having more trouble. I think this course could benefit from some more individual work, especially at the beginning as we are becoming familiar with the material. On the other hand, the advantage of the group work was that there were a lot of opportunities to learn from fellow students and share ideas and discuss the material outside of class. Group work is always good to help prepare for future careers.

The small group projects were advantageous for my own personal knowledge, writing skills, and collation abilities. The larger group (of 13!) was really quite difficult. In the end we pulled everything off but it was hard to work together without leadership and stratification.

Group work can be challenging. It was great to work with everyone in the field and have people shine with their personal skills and teach others. When you have large groups it is sometimes easy to lose the direction of forward progress. Overall it was a good experience.
I learned a lot from group work which makes me becoming more confident and making some friends as well.
Our group for the final project was far too big. A lot of our time was spent coordinating, and ultimately not everyone could fully participate and learn every piece of what went into the project.

There were a few too many group assignments in this class, and having multiple groups for different projects was a bit overwhelming. But at the end of the day, I really enjoyed my groups and made some strong connections through the absurd amount of time we spent together.
The group projects were a bit excessive and it became difficult to schedule time to complete group work towards the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course if you want a good survey of systems-level ecology, don't take the course if you have a busy schedule.

Take full advantage of it, it's awesome! I would also advise students to be patient for the first half and trust the professors to bring everything full circle. I was never frustrated by this, but I know that a number of students expressed confusion over how the different topics and work were connecting. It will become clear, and I think Mark and Os did a great job of building and layering content throughout -- it is thoughtfully done.

Great professors, but a very introductory level course. However, I do look at science and its place in the world very differently. I learned a lot from Oz and Mark's perspective. That alone made the course worthwhile.
Stick with it through the slightly confusing and fast paced beginning of the course. It's worth it in the end. This is a great course.
Know that the beginning is very science heavy, fast paced, and time intensive but changes in the latter half of the semester. It eventually pulls everything together and it becomes really manageable.
Take this class and you will not regret.
Make sure your group size is manageable and that you set your communication and accountability systems early!
The beginning is rough, but it's a great class for expanding your worldview.
